text: There was a man from Ramathaim of the Zuphites in the hill country of Ephraim whose name was Elkanah. He was the son of Jeroham, the son of Elihu, the son of Tohu, the son of Zuph, an Ephraimite.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had two wives. One was named Hannah, and the other was named Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah had no children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every year this man went up from his city to worship and to offer sacrifices to the Lord of Armies at Shiloh. Hophni and Phinehas, the two sons of Eli, were serving there as priests of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day when Elkanah sacrificed, he gave portions of food to his wife Peninnah and to all her sons and daughters,
speaker: Narrator

text: but to Hannah he gave a double portion, because he loved Hannah, but the Lord had kept her from having children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah’s rival kept taunting her to make her miserable, because the Lord had kept Hannah from having children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Year after year, when Hannah went up to the Lord’s house, her rival taunted her, so Hannah would weep and would not eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her husband Elkanah said to her, “Hannah, why are you weeping? Why don’t you eat? Why is your heart so sad? Am I not better to you than ten sons?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Once, when they had finished eating and drinking in Shiloh, Hannah stood up. Eli the priest was sitting on his chair by the doorpost of the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah’s spirit was very distressed, and as she prayed to the Lord, she sobbed and wept many tears.
speaker: Narrator

text: She made a vow and said, “O Lord of Armies, if you will carefully consider the misery of your servant and remember me, and if you do not forget your servant but give your servant a male child, then I will give him to the Lord all the days of his life, and no razor shall ever touch his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As she continued praying before the Lord, Eli was looking at her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah was speaking silently from her heart. Although her lips were moving, her voice could not be heard. Eli thought she was drunk
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to her, “How long are you going to be drunk? Get away from your wine!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah replied, “No, my lord, I am a woman with a very troubled spirit. I have not been drinking wine or beer, but I have poured out my soul to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not regard your servant as a worthless, wicked woman. I have been speaking like this because of my great misery and because of how I have been grieved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eli answered, “Go in peace, and may the God of Israel give you what you have asked for.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Let your servant find favor in your sight.” So the woman went on her way. She ate, and her face no longer looked sad.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They got up early in the morning and worshipped the Lord. They then returned to their home at Ramah.
Elkanah was intimate with Hannah his wife, and the Lord remembered her.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hannah conceived and gave birth to a son. She named him Samuel because she said, “I asked for him from the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When this man Elkanah and his entire household went up to offer the annual sacrifice to the Lord and to fulfill his vow,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hannah did not go up with them, because she said to her husband, “Not until the child is weaned. Then I will bring him, so that he can appear before the Lord and remain there permanently.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her husband Elkanah said to her, “Do whatever you think is best. Wait until you have weaned him. Yes, then the Lord will establish his word.”
So the woman stayed at home, and she nursed her son until she was ready to wean him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she had weaned him, she took him up with her. She also took a three-year-old bull, twenty-five pounds of flour, and a container of wine, and she brought him to the House of the Lord in Shiloh. The boy was ⎣with them. And they brought him before the Lord, and his father killed the sacrifice as he regularly did before the Lord, and he brought⎦ the boy.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had killed the bull, they presented the child to Eli.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Excuse me, my lord. As your soul lives, my lord, I am the woman who stood here next to you, praying to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I prayed for this child, and the Lord has granted me what I asked for.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now I have also dedicated him to the Lord. As long as he lives, he is dedicated to the Lord.” So he worshipped the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hannah prayed and said:
My heart rejoices in the Lord!
In the Lord, my horn is raised high.
My mouth is opened wide against my enemies,
because I find joy in your salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no one holy like the Lord.
Yes, there is no one but you,
and there is no rock like our God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not talk so high and mighty.
Do not let proud words come out of your mouth,
because the Lord is a God who knows.
By him actions are weighed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The bows of powerful warriors are broken.
Those who were staggering are now armed with strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who once were full now hire themselves out for bread,
but those who were hungry are satisfied.
Yes, the childless woman has given birth to seven children,
but she who had many children is weak with sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord puts to death, and he makes alive.
He brings down to the grave, and he raises up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord makes some people poor, and he makes others wealthy.
He brings some low. He raises others up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He raises the poor out of the dust.
He lifts up the needy from the garbage pile.
He makes them sit with nobles.
He gives them a glorious throne as a possession.
The pillars of the earth belong to the Lord.
He has set the world upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will guard the feet of his favored ones,
but the wicked will be put to silence in darkness,
because a person does not prevail by his own strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who oppose the Lord will be broken to pieces.
He will thunder against them in the heavens.
The Lord will judge the ends of the earth.
He will give strength to his king.
He will raise up the horn of his anointed one.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elkanah went home to Ramah, but the young boy served the Lord as an attendant to Eli the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the sons of Eli were wicked scoundrels. They did not know the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The practice of the priests with the people was that whenever anyone offered a sacrifice, while the meat was still boiling, the priest’s servant would come with a three-pronged fork in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He would thrust it into the basin, kettle, caldron, or cooking pot. The priest would then take for himself everything that the fork brought up. This is the way they treated all the Israelites who came to Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before the people had even burned the fat, the priest’s servant would come and tell the person who was making the sacrifice, “Give me meat for the priest to roast, because he will not accept boiled meat from you, but only raw meat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If the man said to him, “Let us burn the fat first. Then take as much as you want,” the servant would say, “No, you must give it to me right now. If you do not, I will take it by force.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the sin of the young men was very serious in the sight of the Lord, because the men were treating the Lord’s offerings with contempt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Samuel ministered before the Lord while he was still a young boy, dressed in a special vest made of linen.
speaker: Narrator

text: His mother would make a little robe for him and bring it to him whenever she came up with her husband to offer the annual sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife, and say, “May the Lord give you offspring from this woman in place of the son she asked for, whom she loaned to the Lord.” Then they would go back to their home.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord came to Hannah with his blessing, and she conceived and gave birth to three sons and two daughters. The child Samuel grew up in the presence of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Eli was very old. He heard about everything that his sons were doing to all Israel and how they were sleeping with the women who served at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to them, “Why do you do such things? I keep hearing from all these people about your evil actions.
speaker: Narrator

text: No, my sons, it is not a good report that I hear! The people are spreading this report everywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text: If one man sins against another, God will mediate for him. But if a man sins against the Lord, who will mediate for him?” But they did not listen to the voice of their father, because the Lord desired to put them to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man Samuel continued to grow, and he increased in favor with both the Lord and with men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A man of God came to Eli and told him this:
This is what the Lord says. Didn’t I clearly reveal myself to the house of your father when they were in Egypt, subject to the house of Pharaoh?
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of all the tribes of Israel, I chose him to be my priest, to go up to my altar, to burn incense, and to wear the special vest before me. I also gave the house of your father all the food offerings from the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you all kick at my sacrifice and at my offering, which I have commanded for my dwelling place? Why do you, Eli, honor your sons more than me? Why do you fatten yourselves with the best of all the offerings from my people Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore this is the declaration of the Lord, the God of Israel: I stated solemnly that your house and the house of your father would walk before me forever. But now the Lord declares, “This will never be! Yes, I will honor those who honor me, but those who despise me will be cursed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, the days are coming when I will cut off your arm and the arm of your father’s house, so that there will never be an old man in your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will see the distress of the dwelling place. Even when things are good for Israel, there shall never be an old man in your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any man of yours whom I do not cut off from my altar will only wear out your eyes with tears and your heart with grief, and all the future generations of your house will die before they reach old age.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will be the sign for you that will come on your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas: In one day they will both die.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will raise up a faithful priest for myself, one who will act according to what is in my heart and in my soul. I will build an enduring house for him, and he will walk before my anointed one forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then anyone who is left in your house will come and bow down to the faithful priest to receive a piece of silver and a loaf of bread. The one who is left will say, “Please appoint me to one of the priests’ offices, so that I can eat a scrap of bread.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The boy Samuel was ministering to the Lord in the presence of Eli. The word of the Lord was rare in those days. Prophetic vision was not common.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it happened that Eli’s eyes had begun to grow dim, so that he could not see. Once when Eli was lying down in his place
speaker: Narrator

text: and God’s lamp had not yet gone out, Samuel was lying down in the Lord’s temple, where God’s ark was.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord called Samuel, and Samuel said, “I am here.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He ran to Eli and said, “I am here, since you called me.”
Eli said, “I did not call. Lie down again.” So he went and lay down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord called once more, “Samuel!”
So Samuel got up and went to Eli and said, “I am here, since you called me.”
He answered, “I did not call, my son. Lie down again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Samuel had not yet experienced the Lord’s presence, that is, the word of the Lord had not yet been revealed to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord called Samuel for the third time. So he got up and went to Eli and said, “I am here, since you called me.”
Then Eli realized that the Lord was calling the young man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Eli said to Samuel, “Go, lie down, and if he calls you, say, ‘Speak, Lord, for your servant is listening.’”
So Samuel went and once again lay down in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord came and stood there and called as he had the other times, “Samuel! Samuel!”
Then Samuel said, “Speak, for your servant is listening.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Samuel, “Look, I am going to do something in Israel that will make both ears of everyone who hears about it tingle.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day I am going to carry out against Eli everything that I have spoken against his house, from beginning to end.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have told him that I am going to judge his house forever because of their guilty behavior, which he knew about. This will happen because his sons brought a curse on themselves, and he did not restrain them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have sworn to the house of Eli that the guilt of Eli’s house shall never be atoned for with sacrifice or offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel lay there until morning. Then he opened the doors to the Lord’s house. Samuel was afraid to tell Eli about the vision.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Eli called to Samuel, “Samuel, my son!”
He said, “I am here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli said, “What is the message that he has spoken to you? Please do not hide it from me. May God punish you severely and double it, if you hide from me one word of all of the things that he spoke to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Samuel told him everything and hid nothing from him.
Eli said, “He is the Lord. Let him do whatever is good in his eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel continued to grow, and the Lord was with him. The Lord let none of his words fall to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all Israel from Dan to Beersheba knew that Samuel was confirmed as a prophet of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued to appear in Shiloh, because at Shiloh the Lord revealed himself to Samuel by the word of the Lord. ⎣So Samuel was confirmed as a prophet of the Lord for all Israel, from one end of the land to the other end.⎦
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the word of Samuel came to all Israel.
⎣Eli was very old, and his sons kept getting worse in their wickedness in the presence of the Lord. In those days the Philistines gathered themselves together for war against Israel.⎦ 
Israel went out to meet the Philistines in battle. The Israelites camped near Ebenezer, and the Philistines camped at Aphek.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines formed battle lines to confront the Israelites. As the battle developed, Israel was defeated by the Philistines, who killed about four thousand of the Israelites lined up on the battlefield.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people had come back into the camp, the elders of Israel said, “Why has the Lord allowed us to be defeated today before the Philistines? Let us bring the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord here from Shiloh, so that it may come into our midst and save us from the hand of our enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people sent word to Shiloh, and from there they brought the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord of Armies, who sits above the cherubim. Hophni and Phinehas, the two sons of Eli, were there with the Ark of the Covenant of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord came into the camp, all Israel shouted with a shout so loud that the earth shook.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard the noise of all the shouting, they asked, “Why is there this loud shouting in the camp of the Hebrews?” They learned that the Ark of the Lord had come into the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines were afraid, so they said, “A god has come into the camp.” They said, “We’re doomed! Nothing like this has happened before.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are doomed! Who can deliver us out of the hand of these mighty gods? These are the gods that struck the Egyptians with every kind of plague in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong and act like men, you Philistines, so that you will not become slaves to the Hebrews, as they have been to you. Act like men and fight!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Philistines fought, and Israel was defeated, and each man fled to his tent. A very great slaughter took place, in which thirty thousand foot soldiers of Israel fell.
speaker: Narrator

text: God’s ark was taken, and Hophni and Phinehas, the two sons of Eli, died.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man from the tribe of Benjamin ran from the battlefield and came to Shiloh that same day. His clothing was torn, and his face was dirty.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived, Eli was there, sitting on his chair beside the road. He was watching, because his heart was trembling with fear for God’s ark. When the man came into the city and told them what had happened, the whole city was in an uproar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Eli heard the noise of the uproar, he said, “What does this noisy commotion mean?”
The man came quickly and told Eli what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eli was ninety-eight years old. His eyes stared straight ahead because he could not see.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The man said to Eli, “I am the one who came from the battlefield. Today I fled from the battlefield.”
Eli said, “What was the outcome, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man who brought the news answered, “Israel has fled from the Philistines, and there has also been a great slaughter among the people. In addition, your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, are dead, and God’s ark has been captured.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man mentioned God’s ark, Eli fell backwards off his seat, which was by the city gate. He broke his neck, and he died, because he was an old man, and he was overweight. He had judged Israel for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: His daughter-in-law, Phinehas’ wife, was pregnant, ready to give birth. When she heard the news that God’s ark had been taken and that her father-in-law and her husband were dead, she crouched down and gave birth, because labor pains had come upon her.
speaker: Narrator

text: As her death approached, the women who stood by her said to her, “Don’t be afraid, for you have given birth to a son.” But she did not respond or pay attention.
speaker: Narrator

text: She named the boy Ichabod and said, “The glory has departed from Israel.” Because God’s ark had been taken, and because of the deaths of her father-in-law and her husband,
speaker: Narrator

text: she said, “The glory has departed from Israel, because God’s ark has been taken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Philistines had captured God’s ark, they brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines took God’s ark and brought it into the house of Dagon and set it beside Dagon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people of Ashdod got up early the next day, there was Dagon—fallen facedown to the ground in front of the Ark of the Lord! So they took Dagon and set him in his place again.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they got up early the following morning, it had happened again! There was Dagon, fallen facedown in front of the Ark of the Lord. The head of Dagon and both of his hands were broken off and were lying on the threshold. Only Dagon’s torso was intact.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why the priests of Dagon and any people who enter Dagon’s temple in Ashdod do not step on the threshold of Dagon to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord’s hand was heavy against the people of Ashdod. He devastated them and struck them with tumors. He struck Ashdod and its surrounding territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Ashdod saw what was taking place, they said, “The Ark of the God of Israel must not stay with us, because his hand is heavy on us and on our god Dagon.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They called together a meeting of all the serens of the Philistines and asked, “What shall we do with the Ark of the God of Israel?”
They answered, “Let the Ark of the God of Israel be carried over to Gath.” So they carried the Ark of the God of Israel there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after they had carried it there, the Lord’s hand was against that city, and there was great panic. He struck the men of the city, both young and old, so that tumors broke out on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they sent God’s ark to Ekron.
When God’s ark came to Ekron, the people of Ekron cried out, “They have brought the Ark of the God of Israel here to kill us and our people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They called a meeting of all the serens of the Philistines, and they said, “Send the Ark of the God of Israel away. Let it go back to its own place, so that it does not kill us and our people.” Indeed, the threat of death caused panic throughout the whole city. The hand of God was very heavy there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men who did not die were struck with tumors, and the outcry from the city went up to heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s ark remained in the country of the Philistines seven months.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines called for the priests and the diviners and asked, “What should we do with the Lord’s ark? Advise us how we should send it back to its place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “If you send away the Ark of the God of Israel, do not send it away empty, but, by all means, send it to him with a restitution offering. Then you will be healed, and you will know why his hand has not been removed from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they said, “What restitution offering should we send to him?”
They said, “There are five serens of the Philistines, so five gold tumors and five gold mice should be sent, because the same plague was on all of you and on your serens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you should make replicas of your tumors and figurines of the mice that are ruining your land, and you will give glory to the God of Israel. Perhaps he will lighten his hand on you, on your gods, and on your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why harden your hearts, as the Egyptians and Pharaoh hardened their hearts? After the Lord had dealt ruthlessly with them, didn’t the Egyptians let the people go, and they departed?
speaker: Narrator

text: “So make a new cart and take two cows that are nursing their calves, cows that have never had a yoke on them. Hitch the cows to the cart, and take their calves away from them and send them home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take the Ark of the Lord and place it on the cart. Place the gold objects, which you are sending to him as a restitution offering, into a box beside the ark. Then send it on its way, and let it go on its own.
speaker: Narrator

text: Watch it. If it goes up on the road toward the border of Israel, to Beth Shemesh, then it is their god who has inflicted this disaster on us. But if not, then we will know that it was not his hand that struck us. It was a coincidence that this happened to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that is what the men did. They took two cows that were nursing calves, hitched them to the cart, and shut up their calves at home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they put the Ark of the Lord on the cart, along with the box containing the gold mice and the replicas of their tumors.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cows headed straight up the road toward Beth Shemesh. They went straight along the highway without stopping, lowing as they went. They did not turn aside to the right or to the left. The serens of the Philistines followed them to the border of Beth Shemesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Beth Shemesh were reaping their wheat harvest in the valley. They looked up and saw the Ark, and they rejoiced to see it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cart came into the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh and stopped there, near the large stone that was there. Then the people split the wood of the cart and offered the cows as a burnt offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites took the Lord’s ark and the box with it, which contained the gold objects, and they put them on the large stone. On that same day, the men of Beth Shemesh offered burnt offerings and sacrifices to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the five serens of the Philistines had seen this, they returned to Ekron that same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the number of gold tumors that the Philistines sent back as a restitution offering to the Lord: one for Ashdod, one for Gaza, one for Ashkelon, one for Gath, and one for Ekron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gold mice also corresponded to the number of all the cities of the Philistines that belonged to the five serens, the fortified cities along with the rural villages. The objects were placed on the large stone on which they had placed the Ark of the Lord. That stone remains in the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord struck some of the men of Beth Shemesh, because they had looked into the Ark of the Lord. He struck seventy men. Then the people mourned, because the Lord had struck the people with such a heavy blow.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Beth Shemesh said, “Who is able to stand before this holy God, the Lord? To whom can we send it to get it away from here?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent messengers to the inhabitants of Kiriath Jearim. They said, “The Philistines have sent back the Ark of the Lord. Come down and take it up for yourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men of Kiriath Jearim came, took the Ark of the Lord, and brought it into Abinadab’s house on the hill. Then they consecrated his son Eleazar to watch over the Ark of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: So from that day the ark stayed in Kiriath Jearim for a long time—twenty years. And the entire house of Israel deeply longed for the return of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to the whole house of Israel, “If you are returning to the Lord with all your heart, put away the foreign gods and the Ashtartes from among you. Direct your hearts to the Lord and serve him only. Then he will deliver you out of the hand of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people of Israel removed the Baals and the Ashtartes and served the Lord only.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Gather all Israel to Mizpah, and I will pray to the Lord for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Israel gathered together at Mizpah. They drew water and poured it out before the Lord. They fasted that day, and they said there, “We have sinned against the Lord.”
Samuel acted as judge for the people of Israel at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard that the Israelites had gathered together at Mizpah, the serens of the Philistines went up against Israel. When the people of Israel heard this, they were afraid of the Philistines,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the people of Israel said to Samuel, “Do not stop crying out for us to the Lord our God, so that he will save us out of the hand of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel took a nursing lamb and offered it as a whole burnt offering to the Lord. He cried out to the Lord on behalf of Israel, and the Lord answered him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Samuel was offering the burnt offering, the Philistines approached to engage in battle with Israel, but on that day the Lord thundered against the Philistines with a loud roar and threw them into a panic, so they were struck down before Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel went out from Mizpah and pursued the Philistines and struck them down until they arrived at a point below Beth Kar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel took a stone and set it up between Mizpah and Shen. He named that place Ebenezer, saying, “The Lord has helped us this far.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Philistines were subdued, and they no longer came into the territory of Israel. The Lord’s hand was against the Philistines all the days of Samuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cities that the Philistines had taken from Israel were restored to Israel. From Ekron all the way to Gath, Israel recovered the territory of those cities from the control of the Philistines. There was also peace between Israel and the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel judged Israel all the days of his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each year he would travel in a circuit to Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpah, and he judged Israel in all those places.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then would return to Ramah, where his home was, and he would also judge Israel there. He also built an altar to the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samuel was old, he appointed his sons as judges over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of his firstborn son was Joel, and the name of his second was Abijah. They served as judges in Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons did not follow in his footsteps. Instead, they turned aside to seek dishonest gain. They took bribes and perverted justice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the elders of Israel gathered together and came to Samuel at Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Look, you are old, and your sons are not walking in your ways. Now appoint a king for us so that he can judge us like all the other nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But in Samuel’s eyes, their request to receive a king to judge them looked evil, so Samuel prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Samuel, “Listen to the voice of the people regarding everything they have said to you, because it is not you whom they have rejected. I am the one they have rejected as king over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is just like all the actions they have taken from the day that I brought them up out of Egypt, right up to this present day. They have forsaken me and served other gods, and now they are also acting the same way toward you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now listen to them. Nevertheless, warn them strongly and show them what the king who reigns over them will do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel told all the words of the Lord to the people, who had asked him for a king.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “This is what the king who reigns over you will do. He will take your sons and make them serve with his chariots and with his teams of horses, and they will have to run ahead of his chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will make them serve as commanders of a thousand soldiers and as commanders of fifty. He will assign some to plow his ground and to reap his harvest. He will assign some to make his weapons and the trappings for his chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your daughters to serve as perfume makers, cooks, and bakers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your fields, your vineyards, and your olive groves, even the best of them, and give them to his officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take a tenth of your seed and of the produce of your vineyards, and he will give it to the members of his court and to his officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take your male servants, your female servants, your best young men, and your donkeys, and he will use them to do his work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take a tenth from your flocks, and you will become his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day you will cry out because of your king whom you have chosen for yourselves, but the Lord will not answer you on that day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people refused to listen to the voice of Samuel. Instead they said, “No, we want to have a king over us,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that we also can be like all the nations, and our king can judge us and lead us out to fight our battles.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel heard all the words of the people, and he repeated them in the hearing of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said to Samuel, “Listen to them, and appoint a king for them.”
So Samuel said to the men of Israel, “Each of you go home to your own city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Benjamin there was a man whose name was Kish. He was the son of Abiel, the son of Zeror, the son of Bekorath, the son of Aphiah, a descendant of Benjamin. Kish was a strong warrior and influential person.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had a son named Saul, who was an impressive young man. Among the men of Israel there was not a better man than Saul. He was a head taller than all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkeys of Saul’s father Kish were lost, so Kish said to his son Saul, “Take one of our young men with you, and go look for the donkeys.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul passed through the hill country of Ephraim and through the land of Shalishah, but they did not find the donkeys. Then they traveled through the land of Sha’alim but found nothing. Then he traveled through the land of the Benjaminites, but they did not find the donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the land of Zuph, Saul said to the young man who was with him, “Come on. Let’s go back. If we don’t, my father will stop worrying about the donkeys and will start worrying about us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the young man said to him, “Wait! In this city there is a man of God, who is highly regarded. Everything he says actually comes true. So let’s go there. Maybe he can tell us which way we should go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to his young man, “If we go, what should we bring for the man? Look, the bread in our bags is used up, and we do not have a gift to bring to the man of God. What do we have with us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man responded to Saul, “Look here. I have a quarter of a shekel of silver in my hand. I will give that to the man of God to tell us which way we should go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (In earlier times in Israel, when a man went to inquire of God, he would say, “Come, let’s go to the seer,” because the man who is now called a prophet used to be called a seer.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said to his servant, “Good advice. Come on! Let’s go!” So they went to the city where the man of God was.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they went up the ascent to the city, they met some young women coming out to draw water, and they asked them, “Is the seer here?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered them, “Yes, he is. He is there just ahead of you. Hurry! He has just come into the city today, because the people are presenting a sacrifice today at the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as you come into the city, you will find him before he goes up to the high place to eat, since the people will not eat until he comes, because he must bless the sacrifice. After that, those who have been invited will eat. So go up, right now, for this is the time for you to find him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went up to the city. Just as they were coming into the city, there was Samuel coming toward them on his way to the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord had revealed this to Samuel the day before Saul came. He had told him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “About this time tomorrow I will send to you a man from the land of Benjamin, and you are to anoint him to be leader over my people Israel. He will save my people from the hand of the Philistines, for I am looking out for my people, because their cry for help has come to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samuel saw Saul, the Lord told him, “There, that is the man I was talking about! He will exercise authority over my people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul approached Samuel in the gateway and said, “Please tell me where the seer’s house is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel answered Saul, “I am the seer. Go up to the high place ahead of me, because you and your men are to eat with me today. In the morning I will let you go, and I will tell you everything that is on your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for your donkeys that were lost three days ago, do not be concerned about them, because they have been found. For who is it that all Israel desires? Isn’t it you and your father’s entire house?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul answered, “But I am just a Benjaminite from the smallest of the tribes of Israel. And my family is the least important of all the families in the tribe of Benjamin. So why do you speak to me like this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel took Saul and his servant and brought them into the dining hall. He seated them at the head of those who had been invited. There were about thirty men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to the cook, “Bring the portion I gave you, the one I told you to set aside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the cook picked up the thigh and all the meat that was on it and placed it before Saul. Samuel said, “Look here, this has been reserved for you! Set it before you and eat, because ever since I said, ‘I have invited the people,’ it has been kept for you for the appointed time.” So Saul ate with Samuel that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had come down from the high place and gone into the city, Samuel spoke with Saul on the flat roof of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: They got up early, about daybreak, and Samuel called to Saul on the housetop, “Get up, so that I may send you on your way.” Saul got up, and the two of them, Saul and Samuel, went outside together.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were going down to the edge of the city, Samuel said to Saul, “Tell the young man to go on ahead of us.” So the young man went on ahead. Then Samuel said, “You stay here, so that I can tell you God’s message.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Samuel took a flask of olive oil, poured it on Saul’s head, kissed him, and told him this:
Hasn’t the Lord anointed you to be ruler over his inheritance?
speaker: Narrator

text: When you leave me today, you will meet two men near Rachel’s tomb, at Zelzah on the border of Benjamin. They will tell you, “The donkeys that you have been looking for have been found. Now your father has stopped worrying about the donkeys and is worried about the two of you. He is asking, ‘What should I do about my son?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: As you go on farther from there, you will come to the oak tree at Tabor. Three men going up to God’s house at Bethel will meet you there. One will be carrying three young goats, another will be carrying three loaves of bread, and the third will be carrying a container of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will greet you, ask how you are doing, and give you two loaves of bread, which you are to accept from their hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, you will come to Gibeah of God, where there is a Philistine garrison. When you come to the city, you will meet a band of prophets coming down from the high place. Musicians with a harp, a hand drum, a flute, and a lyre will be going in front of them, and they will be prophesying.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit of the Lord will rush upon you with power, and you will prophesy with them, and you will become a changed man.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have received these signs, do whatever is appropriate for the occasion, for God is with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go down to Gilgal ahead of me. Watch for me. I will come down to you to offer burnt offerings and to sacrifice fellowship offerings. Wait seven days, until I come to you. Then I will let you know what you are to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Saul was turning away from Samuel to leave, God gave him a changed heart, and all those signs were fulfilled that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to Gibeah, a band of prophets met Saul, and the Spirit of God came upon him with power, and he prophesied among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When everyone who had known him previously saw that Saul was prophesying along with the prophets, the people were surprised and said to each other, “What has happened to the son of Kish? Is even Saul among the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Someone from that area responded, “Who is their father?” Therefore it became a saying: “Is even Saul among the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul had finished prophesying, he arrived at the high place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul’s uncle asked Saul and his servant, “Where did you go?”
Saul said, “To look for the donkeys. But when we realized that we were not succeeding, we went to Samuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s uncle said, “Please tell me what Samuel said to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said to his uncle, “He made it clear to us that the donkeys had been found.”
But Saul did not tell his uncle anything about the matter of the kingship, about which Samuel had also spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel called the people together to the Lord at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the people of Israel, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says. I brought Israel up out of Egypt, and I delivered you from the hand of the Egyptians, and from the hand of all the kingdoms that oppressed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But today you have rejected your God, the one who saves you out of all your disasters and your distress, and you have said to him, ‘You must set a king over us.’ Now line up in the presence of the Lord by your tribes and by your thousands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel brought forward all the tribes of Israel, and the tribe of Benjamin was chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought forward the tribe of Benjamin by its clans, and the clan of the Matrites was chosen. Then Saul the son of Kish was chosen, but when they looked for him, he could not be found.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore they asked the Lord again, “Has the man arrived here yet?”
The Lord answered, “He has. Look, he is is hiding among the baggage.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they ran and brought him from there. When he stood among the people, he was a head taller than any of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said to all the people, “Do you see the one the Lord has chosen? There is no one like him among all the people.”
All the people shouted, “Long live the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel told the people the regulations concerning the kingship, and he wrote them on a scroll, which was placed before the Lord. Then Samuel sent all the people away, each man to his own house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul went home to Gibeah, and the army went with him, those men whose hearts God had touched.
speaker: Narrator

text: But certain worthless good-for-nothings said, “How can this man save us?” They despised him and brought him no gift, but Saul said nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahash the Ammonite went and set up camp against Jabesh Gilead. So all the men of Jabesh said to Nahash, “Make a treaty with us, and we will serve you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahash the Ammonite said to them, “On this condition I will make a treaty with you: I will gouge out the right eye of every one of you in order to dishonor all Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Jabesh said to him, “Give us seven days, so that we can send messengers throughout all the borders of Israel. Then, if there is no one to rescue us, we will come out to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the messengers came to Gibeah of Saul and spoke these words in the hearing of the people, all the people cried out and wept loudly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then Saul came in from the field, following the oxen. Saul asked, “What has upset the people? Why are they weeping?” So they told him about the words of the men of Jabesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul heard those words, the Spirit of God rushed upon him with power, and his anger burned intensely.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took a yoke of oxen and cut them to pieces and sent the pieces throughout all the borders of Israel in the hands of messengers who said, “This is what will be done to the oxen of anyone who does not turn out to follow Saul and Samuel.” The dread of the Lord fell on the people, and they turned out as one man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul counted them in Bezek. The men of Israel totaled three hundred thousand and the men of Judah thirty thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to the messengers who had come, “Tell the men of Jabesh Gilead, ‘Tomorrow, by the time the sun is hot, you will be rescued.’”
The messengers came and told the men of Jabesh, and they were very happy.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men of Jabesh said, “Tomorrow we will come out to you, and you can do with us whatever seems good to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day, Saul split the army into three divisions. They broke into the middle of the Ammonite camp during the last watch before morning and struck them down until the heat of the day. Those who survived were so scattered that no two of them were left together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people said to Samuel, “Who was it who said, ‘Shall Saul reign over us?’ Hand those men over to us, so we can put them to death!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul said, “No one shall be put to death today, because today the Lord has rescued Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel said to the people, “Come! Let’s go to Gilgal and confirm the kingship there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people went to Gilgal, and they made Saul king in the presence of the Lord there at Gilgal. There they sacrificed fellowship offerings before the Lord, and Saul and all the men of Israel held a great celebration there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to all Israel, “You see that I have listened to your voice and to everything that you said to me. I have appointed a king over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, there he is. The king is walking before you. I am old and gray, but my sons are with you. I have walked before you from my youth till this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Here I am. Testify against me before the Lord and before his anointed. Whose ox have I taken? Whose donkey have I taken? Have I defrauded anyone? Have I oppressed anyone? From whose hand have I taken a bribe to turn a blind eye to anything? If so, I will restore it for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “You have not defrauded us, nor oppressed us, neither have you taken anything from anyone’s hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he said to them, “The Lord is witness against you, and his anointed is witness today that you have not found anything in my hand.”
They said, “He is witness.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So this is what Samuel said to the people:
It was the Lord who appointed Moses and Aaron and who brought your fathers up out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, stand here, so that I may present the case against you before the Lord on the basis of all the righteous acts of the Lord, which he did for you and for your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob had gone down into Egypt, your fathers cried out to the Lord, and the Lord sent Moses and Aaron, who brought your fathers out of Egypt and settled them in this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they forgot the Lord their God, so he sold them into the hand of Sisera, the commander of the army of Hazor, and into the hand of the Philistines and into the hand of the king of Moab, and they fought against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cried to the Lord and said, “We have sinned, because we have forsaken the Lord. We have served the Baals and the Ashtartes, but now deliver us out of the hand of our enemies, and we will serve you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sent Jerubbaal, Bedan, Jephthah, and Samuel, and he delivered you out of the hand of your enemies on every side, and you lived in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when you saw that Nahash king of the Ammonites was coming against you, even though the Lord your God was your king, you said to me, “No, we want a king to reign over us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now look, here is the king you have chosen, the king you asked for. You see, the Lord has set a king over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you fear the Lord and serve him and listen to his voice and do not rebel against the mouth of the Lord, then both you and the king who reigns over you will be following the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you do not listen to the Lord’s voice but rebel against the mouth of the Lord, then the Lord’s hand will be against you, as it was against your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, take your positions here, and see this great thing that the Lord is about to do right in front of your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t today the time of wheat harvest? I will call to the Lord, and he will send thunder and rain, so that you may know and see that your wickedness is great, that wickedness which you have done in the Lord’s sight by asking for a king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel called to the Lord, and the Lord sent thunder and rain that day. Then all the people were very afraid of the Lord and of Samuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people said to Samuel, “Pray to the Lord your God for your servants so that we do not die, for we have added to all our sins also this evil, that we asked for a king for ourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to the people, “Do not be afraid. You have indeed done all this evil. Nevertheless, do not turn away from following the Lord, but serve the Lord with all your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not turn away to pursue empty things that cannot help you or save you, because they are empty.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sake of his great name, the Lord will not forsake his people, because the Lord was pleased to make you his own people for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for me, it is unthinkable that I should sin against the Lord by ceasing to pray for you. Instead I will instruct you in the way that is good and right.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above all, fear the Lord, and serve him in truth, with all your heart, considering the great things he has done for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you keep doing evil, you will be swept away, both you and your king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was thirty years old when he became king, and he reigned over Israel forty-two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul chose for himself three thousand men of Israel. Two thousand were with Saul at Mikmash and in the hill country near Bethel, and one thousand were with Jonathan at Gibeah of Benjamin. He sent the rest of the people to their own tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan struck the Philistine garrison that was in Geba, and the Philistines heard about it. Saul blew the ram’s horn throughout the land and said, “Let the Hebrews hear!”
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel heard that Saul had struck the garrison of the Philistines and that Israel had become a stench to the Philistines. The people were summoned to meet Saul at Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines assembled their forces to fight against Israel with three thousand chariots, six thousand charioteers, and soldiers as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They came up and camped at Mikmash, east of Beth Aven.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Israel saw that they were in trouble because their army was under pressure, the people hid themselves in caves, in thickets, among the rocks, in dugouts, and in cisterns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Hebrews had gone across the Jordan River to the territory of Gad and Gilead, but Saul remained in Gilgal, and all the people who remained with him were shaking with fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: He waited there seven days, the time specified by Samuel, but Samuel did not come to Gilgal, and the people were starting to scatter from Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said, “Bring me the burnt offering and the fellowship offering.” He then presented the burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: No sooner had he finished presenting the burnt offering than Samuel arrived. Saul went out to meet him and greet him with a blessing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Samuel said, “What have you done?”
Saul said, “I saw that the people were scattering from me, that you did not come within the set number of days, and that the Philistines had assembled their forces at Mikmash.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I said, ‘Now the Philistines will come down against me at Gilgal, and I have not sought the favor of the Lord.’ So I forced myself to offer the burnt offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to Saul, “You have acted foolishly. You have not kept the command which the Lord your God gave to you. The Lord would have established your kingship over Israel forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now your kingship will not continue. The Lord has sought for himself a man after his own heart, and the Lord has appointed him to be ruler over his people, because you have not obeyed the command the Lord gave you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samuel set out and went up from Gilgal. ⎣The rest of the people followed Saul to meet the army. They went up from Gilgal⎦ to Gibeah of Benjamin. Saul counted the people who were present with him. There were about six hundred men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul, and his son Jonathan, and the people who were present with them stayed in Geba of Benjamin, but the Philistines camped at Mikmash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Raiding parties set out from the camp of the Philistines in three groups. One group headed down the road toward Ophrah, toward the land of Shual.
speaker: Narrator

text: Another group headed down the road to Beth Horon, and the third group headed toward the position on the border that looks down on the Valley of Zeboim, toward the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time no blacksmith could be found throughout the whole land of Israel, because the Philistines said, “If we allow this, the Hebrews will make swords or spears for themselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the Israelites had to go down to the Philistines to get their plowshares, mattocks, axes, and sickles sharpened.
speaker: Narrator

text: The price was two thirds of a shekel to sharpen plowshares and mattocks and one third of a shekel for pitchforks and axes and to repair ox goads.
speaker: Narrator

text: The result was that when the day of battle came, no swords or spears were found in the hands of any of the people who were with Saul and Jonathan. Only Saul and his son Jonathan had them.
speaker: Narrator

text: A garrison of the Philistines took up a position by the pass at Mikmash.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Saul’s son Jonathan said to the young man who carried his armor, “Come on! Let’s go over to the Philistines’ garrison that is on the other side.” But he did not tell his father
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul, who was staying on the outskirts of Gibeah, under the pomegranate tree that is in Migron. The people who were with Saul amounted to about six hundred men,
speaker: Narrator

text:
including Ahijah son of Ahitub. (Ahitub was the brother of Ichabod and the son of Phinehas, who was the son of Eli, the priest of the Lord in Shiloh.) Ahijah was wearing the special vest.
The men did not know that Jonathan was gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: On each side of the pass which Jonathan needed to cross in order to go over to the Philistine garrison, there was a cliff with a sharp outcropping of rock. The name of one was Bozez, and the name of the other was Seneh.
speaker: Narrator

text: One cliff rose up on the north side in front of Mikmash, and the other was on the south side in front of Geba.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to the young man who carried his armor, “Come on! Let’s go over to the garrison of these uncircumcised fellows. It may be that the Lord will exert his power for us, for the Lord is not limited. He can save by many or by few.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His armor bearer said to him, “Do everything that is in your heart. Give it all you’ve got! I am with you heart and soul.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan said, “Here’s the plan. We will cross over to them, and we will let them see us.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they say to us, ‘Stay there until we come to you!’ then we will stay right where we are. We will not go up to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they say, ‘Come up to us!’ then we will go up, because the Lord has delivered them into our hand. This will be the sign for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So both of them showed themselves to the garrison of the Philistines, and the Philistines said, “What do you know! The Hebrews are coming out of the holes where they have been hiding!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Jonathan and his armor bearer appeared, the men of the garrison responded, “Come up to us. We have something to show you!”
So Jonathan said to his armor bearer, “Follow me, because the Lord has delivered them into Israel’s hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan climbed up on his hands and feet, and his armor bearer followed him. The Philistines fell wounded before Jonathan, and his armor bearer followed him, killing them as he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: That first blow struck by Jonathan and his armor bearer killed about twenty men within about half an acre of land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Panic spread throughout the entire Philistine army, both those in the camp and those in the open country. The garrison and the raiding parties also panicked. The earth quaked, and there was a panic sent by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s sentries at Geba of Benjamin looked out and saw the noisy crowd melting away and scattering in every direction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said to the people who were with him, “Take roll call, and see who is missing from us.” When they took roll call, they realized that Jonathan and his armor bearer were not there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to Ahijah, “Bring the special vest of God here.” (The special vest of God was with the Israelites at that time.)
speaker: Narrator

text: While Saul was talking to the priest, the uproar in the camp of the Philistines continued and got even louder, so Saul said to the priest, “Stop drawing lots!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and all the troops who were with him assembled and joined the battle. There they saw the panicked Philistines striking each other with their swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Hebrews from all around, who had previously sided with the Philistines and had joined them in their camp, deserted them to join the Israelites who were with Saul and Jonathan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise, when all the men of Israel who had hidden themselves in the hill country of Ephraim heard that the Philistines were fleeing, they joined the battle and stuck to the Philistines in close pursuit.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord saved Israel that day, and the battle progressed as far as Beth Aven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel were pushed to their limits that day, because Saul had imposed an oath on the people: “Cursed is the man who eats any food until it is evening and I have been avenged on my enemies.” So none of the people tasted any food.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire army had come into a forest, and there was honey on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the army came into the forest, they saw the honey dripping, but no one put his hand to his mouth, because the people were afraid as a result of the oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan, however, had not heard his father put the people under oath. So he stuck out the tip of the staff that was in his hand, dipped it into the honeycomb, and put his hand to his mouth, and he was revived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the soldiers responded and said, “Your father specifically placed the people under an oath, saying, ‘Cursed is the man who eats food today.’ That is why the people are so weak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan said, “My father has caused trouble for the land. See how I have been revived, because I tasted a little of this honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much better it would have been today if the people had eaten freely from the plunder taken from their enemies. The slaughter among the Philistines would have been even greater.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites struck down the Philistines that day from Mikmash to Aijalon. The troops were very weak,
speaker: Narrator

text: so they pounced on the plunder. They took sheep, cattle, and calves and slaughtered them on the spot, and they ate them with the blood still in them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul was told, “Look, the people are sinning against the Lord. They are eating meat with the blood still in it.”
Saul said, “You have acted unfaithfully. Roll a large stone over here to me right now!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Spread out among the people and tell them, ‘Have each man bring his ox or his sheep here to me. Kill them here, and eat them, but do not sin against the Lord by eating meat with the blood still in it.’” So that night each person brought his ox with him, and together they killed them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul built an altar to the Lord. This was the first altar which he built to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said, “We will pursue the Philistines by night and take plunder from them until the morning light. We will not allow a man of them to survive.”
The people responded, “Do whatever seems good to you.”
But the priest said, “We should consult God here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul inquired of God, “Shall I pursue the Philistines? Will you deliver them into Israel’s hand?” But God did not answer him that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said, “Come over here, all you pillars of the people, and let us find out what sin has been committed today.
speaker: Narrator

text: For, as the Lord lives, who saves Israel, even if it is my son Jonathan, he must surely die.” But there was not a man among all the people who responded to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Saul said to all Israel, “You stand on one side, and I and my son Jonathan will be on the other side.”
The people said to Saul, “Do whatever seems good to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Saul said to the Lord, the God of Israel, ⎣“Why have you not answered your servant today? If the fault is in me or my son Jonathan, respond with Urim, but if the fault is with the men of Israel,⎦ respond with Thummim.”
Then Jonathan and Saul were chosen, and the people were not chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said, “Cast lots between me and Jonathan my son. ⎣The person the Lord identifies by lot shall be put to death.”
But the people said to Saul, “Absolutely not.” But Saul overruled the people, so they cast lots between him and Jonathan his son,⎦ and Jonathan was selected by lot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Saul said to Jonathan, “Tell me what you have done!”
Jonathan told him, “I just tasted a little honey with the tip of the staff that was in my hand, and now I must die?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “May God punish me severely and double it, if you are not put to death, Jonathan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people said to Saul, “Should Jonathan die? He has accomplished this great deliverance for Israel. Absolutely not! As the Lord lives, not one hair of his head shall fall to the ground, because he has worked with God today!” So the people rescued Jonathan, so that he did not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul gave up pursuing the Philistines, and the Philistines went back to their own places.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul had assumed the kingship over Israel, he fought against all his enemies on every side: against Moab, against the Ammonites, against Edom, against the kings of Zobah, and against the Philistines. Wherever he turned, he inflicted punishment.
speaker: Narrator

text: He fought valiantly. He struck the Amalekites and delivered Israel out of the hands of those who had plundered them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Saul were Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malkishua. The names of his two daughters were Merab, the firstborn, and Michal, the younger.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of Saul’s wife was Ahinoam daughter of Ahima’az. The name of the commander of his army was Abner son of Ner, Saul’s uncle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kish was Saul’s father, and Ner, Abner’s father, was the son of Abiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was fierce warfare against the Philistines all the days of Saul. Whenever Saul noticed any heroic man or strong warrior, he would take him into his service.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to Saul, “The Lord sent me to anoint you to be king over his people Israel. Therefore, listen to the voice of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord of Armies says. I will repay Amalek for what they did to Israel when they blocked Israel’s way as it was coming up out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and strike Amalek. Devote everything they have to destruction. Do not spare them. Kill both men and women, infants and nursing babies, oxen and sheep, camels and donkeys.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul summoned the troops and organized them for battle at Telaim. There were two hundred thousand foot soldiers and ten thousand men from Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul came to the city of Amalek and set up an ambush in the ravine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to the Kenites, “Go! Leave! Get away from the Amalekites, so that I do not destroy you along with them, because you showed kindness to all the people of Israel when they came up out of Egypt.” So the Kenites moved away from the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul struck the Amalekites from Havilah all the way to Shur, which borders Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took Agag, the king of the Amalekites, alive, and he devoted all the people to destruction with the edge of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul and the people spared Agag and the best of the sheep, the cattle, the fattened calves, and the lambs, along with everything else that was good, because they were not willing to devote them to destruction. But everything that was undesirable and worthless, that they devoted to destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to Samuel:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I regret that I have set up Saul to be king, for he has turned back from following me, and he has not carried out my words.” Samuel was angry, and he cried to the Lord all night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel got up to meet Saul early in the morning, but Samuel was told, “Saul went to Carmel, and he set up a monument for himself there. Then he turned and continued down to Gilgal.”
⎣So Samuel went to Saul, and there he saw Saul, offering a burnt offering to the Lord from the best of the spoils that he had brought from the Amalekites.⎦
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samuel came to Saul, Saul said to him, “You are blessed by the Lord! I have carried out the word of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Then what does this mean—this bleating of sheep in my ears and the lowing of cattle that I hear?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “They have been brought here from the Amalekites, because the people spared the best of the sheep and the cattle to sacrifice to the Lord your God. But we have completely destroyed the rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Samuel said to Saul, “Stop right there! Let me tell you what the Lord said to me last night.”
He said to him, “Tell me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Though you were insignificant in your own sight, you were made the head of the tribes of Israel. The Lord anointed you king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord sent you on a mission and said, ‘Go and devote the Amalekites, that sinful people, to destruction. Fight against them until they are exterminated.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Why didn’t you listen to the voice of the Lord? Why did you swoop down on the plunder and do what was evil in the Lord’s sight?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to Samuel, “But I have obeyed the voice of the Lord and have completed the mission that the Lord gave me. I have captured Agag king of Amalek, and I have completely destroyed the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people took some of the plunder: sheep, cattle, and the best of what was devoted to destruction, to sacrifice to the Lord your God in Gilgal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Does the Lord take as much pleasure in burnt offerings and sacrifices, as in obedience to the voice of the Lord? Know this! To obey is better than sacrifice, and to pay attention is better than the fat of rams.
speaker: Narrator

text: For rebellion is the same as the sin of witchcraft, and arrogance is like having useless idols or consulting household gods. Because you have rejected the word of the Lord, he has also rejected you as king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to Samuel, “I have sinned, for I have transgressed against the command of the Lord, as well as against your words, because I was afraid of the people, so I listened to their voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, please pardon my sin and come back with me again, so that I may worship the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Samuel said to Saul, “I will not return with you, because you have rejected the word of the Lord, and the Lord has rejected you from being king over Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Samuel turned to leave, Saul grabbed the edge of his robe, and it tore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said to him, “The Lord has torn the kingdom of Israel away from you today, and he has given it to a neighbor of yours who is better than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Splendor of Israel will not lie or change his mind, because he is not a man, who changes his mind.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “I have sinned, but please honor me now before the elders of my people and before Israel. Come back with me, so that I may worship the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel went back with Saul, and Saul worshipped the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Samuel said, “Bring Agag the king of the Amalekites here to me!”
Agag came to him confidently. He said, “Surely the bitterness of death is past.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “As your sword has made women childless, so your mother will be childless among women!” Then Samuel cut Agag to pieces before the Lord in Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel then went to Ramah, and Saul went up to his house at Gibeah of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Until the day of his death, Samuel never again came to see Saul. Samuel did, however, mourn for Saul, but the Lord regretted that he had made Saul king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Samuel, “How long will you mourn for Saul, since I have rejected him as king over Israel? Fill your horn with oil and go. I am sending you to Jesse of Bethlehem, for I see a king for myself among his sons.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said, “How can I go? If Saul hears about it, he will kill me.”
The Lord said, “Take a heifer with you and say, ‘I have come to sacrifice to the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Invite Jesse to the sacrifice, and I will let you know what you are to do. You are to anoint for me the person that I point out to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel did what the Lord had told him to do and went to Bethlehem. Trembling with fear, the elders of the city came to meet him. They said, “Do you come in peace?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Yes, in peace. I have come to sacrifice to the Lord. Consecrate yourselves, and come with me to the sacrifice.” He consecrated Jesse and his sons and invited them to the sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had come, he looked at Eliab and said, “Certainly this is the Lord’s anointed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Samuel, “Do not look at his appearance or at how tall he is, because I have rejected him. For the Lord does not look at things the way man does. For man looks at the outward appearance, but the Lord looks at the heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesse called Abinadab and had him pass in front of Samuel. But Samuel said, “The Lord has not chosen this one either.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesse had Shammah pass by. But Samuel said, “The Lord has not chosen this one either.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse had seven of his sons pass before Samuel. Samuel said to Jesse, “The Lord has not chosen any of these.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said to Jesse, “Is that all of the young men?”
Jesse said, “There still is the youngest, but he is tending the sheep.”
Samuel said to Jesse, “Send for him, for we cannot sit down to eat until he comes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent for him and brought him in. David had red hair and striking eyes, and was good-looking. The Lord said, “Get up! Anoint him, because this is the one.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed him in the presence of his brothers. The Spirit of the Lord rushed on David with power from that day forward. After that Samuel set out and returned to Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit of the Lord departed from Saul, and an evil spirit from the Lord tormented him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul’s servants said to him, “Please listen to us. An evil spirit from God is tormenting you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our lord, please command your servants who are here with you to seek out a man who is skilled at playing the lyre. Then when the evil spirit from God is on you, he will play the lyre, and you will feel better.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said to his servants, “Find a man who can play well and bring him to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the young attendants replied, “As a matter of fact, I have seen a son of Jesse from Bethlehem who is a skillful player. He is a strong, brave man, fit for war. He shows good judgment in what he says and is a handsome man. And the Lord is with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul sent messengers to Jesse and said, “Send me your son David, who is with the sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse took a donkey loaded with bread, a container of wine, and a young goat, and he sent them with his son David to Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: David came to Saul and stood before him. Saul loved him, and David became his armor bearer.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul sent to Jesse, saying, “Permit David to remain and serve me, for I am very pleased with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the spirit from God came over Saul, David would take the lyre in his hand and play. So Saul would be soothed and feel better, and the evil spirit would depart from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Philistines gathered their troops for battle. They gathered at Sokoh, which belongs to Judah, and they camped between Sokoh and Azekah at Ephes Dammim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and the men of Israel also gathered together and camped in the Valley of Elah. They lined up in battle formation opposite the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines took up a position in front of the mountain on one side of the valley, and the Israelites stationed themselves in front of the mountain on the other side of the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: A challenger who represented the Philistines came out from the camp of the Philistines. He was named Goliath of Gath. He was nine feet, six inches tall.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had a bronze helmet on his head, and he wore scaled body armor, which was made of more than one hundred pounds of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had bronze greaves on his shins and a bronze spear slung between his shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The shaft of his spear was like a weaver’s beam, and his spearhead was made of fifteen pounds of iron. His shield bearer went out ahead of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He would stand up and shout to the armies of Israel, “Why have you come out to line up in battle formation? I am a Philistine, and you are servants of Saul, aren’t you? Choose a man to represent you, and let him come down to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he is able to fight with me and kill me, we will be your servants. But if I overcome him and kill him, you will become our servants, and you will serve us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine would say, “I defy the ranks of Israel today! Give me a man, and we will fight each other!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul and all Israel heard those words of the Philistine, they lost their courage and were terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David was the son of an Ephrathite from Bethlehem in Judah, whose name was Jesse. Jesse had eight sons. In the days of Saul, Jesse was a very old man.
speaker: Narrator

text: The three oldest sons of Jesse had accompanied Saul to the battleground. The names of his three sons who went to the battle were his firstborn Eliab, next Abinadab, and third Shammah.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was the youngest son. The three oldest accompanied Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: During this time David went back and forth from Saul to take care of his father’s sheep at Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine came out each morning and evening for forty days and presented his challenge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse said to his son David, “Take twenty-five pounds of this roasted grain and these ten loaves of bread for your brothers. Deliver them quickly to the camp for your brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also take these ten blocks of cheese to the commander of their unit. See how your brothers are doing and bring back some assurance they are okay.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Saul, David’s brothers, and all the men of Israel were in the Valley of Elah to fight with the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: David got up early in the morning and left the sheep with someone who would watch them. He took the supplies and set out as Jesse had commanded him. He arrived at the outer defense line of the camp just as the army was marching out to line up in battle formation, shouting war cries as they went.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel and the Philistines were lining up for battle, one formation against the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: After David had handed over his provisions to the supply officer, he ran to the battlefront, where he met and greeted his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was talking with them there, he saw the Philistine challenger named Goliath of Gath coming up out of the ranks of the Philistines. He repeated his usual words, and David heard them.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Whenever they saw the man, all the men of Israel fled from him and were terrified.)
speaker: Narrator
