text: An Israelite had said, “Have you seen this man who has come up? He keeps coming up to taunt Israel. The king will give great riches to the man who kills him. He will give his daughter to him in marriage and make his father’s house exempt from taxes in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David spoke to the men who stood near him. He asked, “What shall be done for the man who kills this Philistine and takes away the disgrace from Israel? Who is this uncircumcised Philistine who dares to defy the troops of the living God?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people again told him what would be done for the man who killed Goliath.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Eliab, David’s oldest brother, heard David speaking to the men, he burned with anger against David. He said, “Why have you come down? Who is taking care of those few sheep in the wilderness? I know your pride and the mischief in your heart. You have come down just to see the battle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “What have I done now? Can’t I say anything?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David turned away from him toward another person, and he asked the same thing again, and the soldiers again answered him the same way.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard what David said, they reported it to Saul, and he sent for David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Do not let anyone lose heart because of this Philistine! Your servant will go and fight him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul said to David, “You cannot go against this Philistine to fight with him, because you are just a boy, and he has been a warrior since he was a youth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Your servant has been taking care of his father’s sheep. When a lion or a bear came and took a lamb from the flock,
speaker: Narrator

text: I went after it and struck it and rescued the lamb out of its mouth. When the lion reared up against me, I grabbed it by its mane, struck it, and killed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant struck both the lion and the bear. This uncircumcised Philistine will be like one of them, since he has defied the ranks of the living God.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David added, “The Lord, who delivered me from the paw of the lion and from the paw of the bear, will deliver me from the hand of this Philistine.”
Saul said to David, “Go then! May the Lord be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul dressed David in his own gear. He placed a bronze helmet on his head and dressed him in scaled body armor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David strapped his sword over his gear. David tried to walk around in them, since he had never trained with this kind of equipment before.
David said to Saul, “I cannot go in these, because I have never trained with them.” So David took them off.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David took his staff in his hand and picked five smooth stones out of the stream bed and put them into the pouch of his shepherd’s bag. He took his sling in his hand and approached the Philistine.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine kept walking and got closer and closer to David. The man who was carrying his shield was walking ahead of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistine got a good look at David, he despised him, because David was just a boy, nothing but a good-looking, red-headed boy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine said to David, “Am I a dog, that you come against me with sticks?” The Philistine cursed David by his gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistine said to David, “Come to me, and I will feed your flesh to the birds of the air and to the wild animals of the countryside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to the Philistine, “You come against me with a sword, with a spear, and with a javelin, but I come against you in the name of the Lord of Armies, the God of the ranks of Israel, whom you have defied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Today the Lord will hand you over to me. I will strike you down and cut off your head. Today I will give the dead bodies of the army of the Philistines to the birds of the air and to the wild animals of the earth. Then all the earth will know that there is a God in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all those gathered here will know that the Lord does not save with sword and spear, for the battle belongs to the Lord, and he will deliver you into our hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, when the Philistine started advancing to attack David, David ran quickly toward the battle line to meet the Philistine.
speaker: Narrator

text: David put his hand into his bag, took a stone from it, shot it from his sling, and struck the Philistine on the forehead. The stone sank into his forehead, and he fell facedown to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David defeated the Philistine with a sling and a stone. He struck the Philistine and killed him, even though David did not have a sword in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So David ran, stood over the Philistine, took hold of his sword, drew it out of its sheath, killed him, and cut off his head with it.
When the Philistines saw that their champion was dead, they fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel and Judah got up, cheering loudly, and pursued the Philistines toward the entrance of the valley, all the way to the gates of Ekron. Fatally-wounded Philistines lined the road from Sha’araim all the way to Gath and Ekron.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites returned from pursuing the Philistines, they plundered their camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took the head of the Philistine and brought it to Jerusalem, but he put the Philistine’s armor and weapons into his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Saul saw David go out against the Philistine, he said to Abner, the commander of the army, “Abner, whose son is this young man?”
Abner said, “As your soul lives, my King, I do not know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Inquire whose son the young man is!”
speaker: Narrator

text: As David returned from striking down the Philistine, Abner took him and brought him before Saul, with the head of the Philistine in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said to him, “Whose son are you, young man?”
David answered, “I am the son of your servant Jesse of Bethlehem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had finished speaking to Saul, the soul of Jonathan became bound to the soul of David, and Jonathan loved David as he loved his own soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul took David into his service that day and would not let him go back to his father’s house anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan and David made a covenant, because Jonathan loved David as his own soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan took off the robe that he was wearing and gave it to David, as well as his other gear, including his sword, his bow, and his belt.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went out wherever Saul sent him, and he was successful. So Saul put him in charge of a group of soldiers. All the people approved, as did Saul’s officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the army was coming back from battle, when David was returning from striking down the Philistine, women came out from all the cities of Israel to meet King Saul with singing and dancing, with joyful music, with hand drums, and with noisemakers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The women sang to each other as they played:
Saul has slain his thousands,
and David his ten thousands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul became furious, because he resented this statement. He said, “They have credited David with tens of thousands, but to me they have credited only thousands. What more can be given to him but the kingship?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul eyed David suspiciously from that day on.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day, an evil spirit from God overcame Saul, and in a frenzy he prophesied inside the house. David had a lyre in his hand. He was playing as he did day by day. Saul had his spear in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He hurled the spear, because he thought, “I will pin David to the wall!” But David escaped from his presence twice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was afraid of David, because the Lord was with David but had departed from Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul sent David away from his court and made him a commander over a unit of a thousand. So David led the army out to battle and back again.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was successful in everything he did, and the Lord was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul saw that David was so successful, he was even more afraid of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all Israel and Judah loved David, because he led them out to battle and back again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to David, “Look, here is my oldest daughter Merab. I will give her to you as your wife. Just be a strong warrior for me, and fight the Lord’s battles.” For Saul thought, “It won’t be my hand against him, but it will be the hand of the Philistines against him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Who am I, and what is the status of my father’s clan in Israel, that I would be able to become the son-in-law of the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time came that Saul’s daughter Merab was supposed to have been given to David, she was given to Adriel of Meholah as his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Michal, Saul’s other daughter, loved David. When they told Saul about it, this situation pleased him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said, “I will give her to him, so that she will be a snare for him, and the hand of the Philistines will be against him.”
So Saul said to David, “Today you have another opportunity to become my son-in-law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul commanded his officials to speak with David privately and to say, “Look, the king is delighted with you, and all his officials love you, so you should become the king’s son-in-law.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul’s officials spoke those words to David’s ears.
But David said, “Does it seem to you to be a trivial thing for me to be the king’s son-in-law, since I am a poor man and not highly regarded?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul’s officials told him what David had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul said, “Tell David that the king desires no price for the bride except one hundred foreskins of the Philistines, for revenge against the king’s enemies.” Saul intended to make David fall by the hand of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul’s officials told David these words, David was very pleased to become the king’s son-in-law. Before the deadline,
speaker: Narrator

text:
David got up and went out with his men and killed two hundred men of the Philistines. Then David brought their foreskins and counted them out for the king, so that he could become the king’s son-in-law.
Then Saul gave his daughter Michal to David as his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul realized that the Lord was with David and that Michal, his daughter, loved David.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul was even more afraid of David, and he was hostile to David all the time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The commanders of the Philistines were regularly going out for battle, and as often as they went out, David was more successful than all the other officers of Saul. So his name was highly regarded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul told his son Jonathan and all his officials that they should kill David. But Saul’s son Jonathan had great admiration and respect for David.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jonathan told David, “My father Saul wants to kill you. So be careful tomorrow morning. Settle down in a hiding place and conceal yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will go out and stand beside my father in the field where you are, and I will talk with my father about you. I will see what the situation is, and I will tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan spoke favorably about David to his father Saul. He said to him, “The king should not sin against his servant David, because he has not sinned against you, and his actions have served you very well.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took his life into his hands when he struck the Philistine, and the Lord brought about a great victory for all Israel. You saw it, and you celebrated. Why then would you sin against innocent blood by killing David without cause?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul listened to the advice of Jonathan, and Saul swore, “As the Lord lives, he shall not be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jonathan called David and told him about all those things. Then Jonathan brought David to Saul, and he served in his presence as he had before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, war broke out again. David went out and fought against the Philistines and inflicted a severe defeat on them, and they fled from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: An evil spirit from the Lord came upon Saul as he sat in his house with his spear in his hand. David was playing the lyre.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul tried to pin David to the wall with the spear, but David evaded Saul’s attempt, and Saul’s spear stuck in the wall. That night David fled and successfully escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul sent messengers to watch David’s house and to kill him in the morning, but David’s wife Michal told him, “If you do not do something to save your life tonight, by tomorrow you will be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Michal let David down through the window. He took off, got away, and escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Michal took a household idol and laid it in the bed. She put something made of goat hair on its head and covered the statue with clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul sent messengers to capture David, she said, “He is sick.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul sent the messengers to see David for themselves. He said, “Bring him to me on the bed, so I can kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the messengers came in, they saw that the idol was in the bed with the goat hair on its head.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said to Michal, “Why have you deceived me like this and let my enemy go, so that he has escaped?”
Michal answered Saul, “He said to me, ‘Let me go! Why should I have to kill you?’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So David ran away and successfully escaped.
David came to Samuel at Ramah and told him about everything that Saul had done to him. So he and Samuel went and stayed in Naioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was told, “Look, David is at Naioth in Ramah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul sent messengers to seize David, but when they saw an assembly of the prophets prophesying, with Samuel standing there as their leader, the Spirit of God came on Saul’s messengers, and they also prophesied.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul was told about it, he sent other messengers, and they also prophesied. So Saul sent messengers a third time, and they also prophesied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Saul himself went to Ramah and came to the large cistern at Seku. He asked, “Where are Samuel and David?”
Someone told him, “They are at Naioth in Ramah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul headed for Naioth in Ramah. Then the Spirit of God came on him also, and he walked along prophesying, until he came to Naioth in Ramah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also stripped off his clothing and prophesied in the presence of Samuel. He fell down and lay there naked all that day and all that night. Therefore it is said, “Is Saul also among the prophets?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David fled from Naioth in Ramah. He came to Jonathan and asked, “What have I done? Am I guilty of something? What is my sin against your father that makes him seek my life?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to him, “A curse on me if that happens. You will not die. Look, my father does nothing whether important or unimportant without telling me about it. Why would my father hide this from me? It is not so.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David took an oath and said, “Your father certainly knows that I have found favor in your eyes, so he might say, ‘Do not let Jonathan know about this, or he will be very upset.’ But as surely as the Lord lives, and as surely as your soul lives, there is only a step between me and death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan said to David, “Ask me for whatever you really want, and I will do it for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Jonathan, “Listen, tomorrow is the new moon, and I am expected to dine with the king, but let me go so that I can hide in the countryside until the evening of the third day.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your father misses me at all, say, ‘David urged me to excuse him so that he could run to Bethlehem, his hometown, because it is the annual sacrifice there for his entire family.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If he says, ‘That is fine,’ your servant will be at peace. But if it really displeases him, then you will know that he is planning evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must show kindness to your servant, because you have made a covenant in the name of the Lord with me, your servant. But if I am guilty of anything, kill me yourself. Why should you bring me to your father?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said, “A curse on me if that occurs, because if I knew that my father was planning to harm you, wouldn’t I tell you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to Jonathan, “Who will tell me if your father gives you a harsh response?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to David, “Come, let’s go out into the field.” So the two of them went out into the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to David, “I swear by the Lord, the God of Israel! About this time tomorrow or the day after, when I have tested my father to see if he is favorably inclined toward David, I will send word to you so that you hear about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord punish Jonathan severely and double it, if my father is planning to harm you and I do not disclose it to you and send you on your way, so that you may go in peace. May the Lord be with you, as he has been with my father.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must show the mercy of the Lord to me, not only while I am still alive, so that I do not die,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you also must not cut off your mercy from my house forever—no, not even when the Lord has cut off every one of the enemies of David from the face of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David, saying, “May the Lord demand an accounting from David’s enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jonathan had David repeat the oath, because of the love that he had for him, for he loved him as he loved his own soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to him, “Tomorrow is the new moon, and you will be missed, because your seat will be empty.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day, go down quickly to the place where you hid on the previous occasion and stay by the stone named Ezel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will shoot three arrows off to the side of it, as if I were shooting at a target.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send the boy out and say, ‘Go and find the arrows!’ If I yell to the boy, ‘Hey! The arrows are closer this way. Come and pick them up,’ then you can come to me, because you are safe and, as the Lord lives, there is no danger.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I yell to the boy, ‘Hey! The arrows are farther out,’ then go on your way, for the Lord has sent you away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Concerning this matter that you and I have spoken about, the Lord stands as a witness between you and me forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David hid in the countryside. When the new moon came, the king sat down to eat his meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sat at his usual seat next to the wall. Jonathan was across from him, and Abner sat next to Saul, but David’s place was empty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, Saul did not say anything that day, since he thought, “Something has happened to him to make him ceremonially unclean. That’s what it is—he must be unclean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day after the new moon, the second day of the month, David’s place was still empty. So Saul asked his son Jonathan, “Why didn’t the son of Jesse come to the meal, either yesterday or today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan answered Saul, “David begged me for permission to go to Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, ‘Please let me go, because our family has a sacrifice in the city. My brother has ordered me to be there. Now, if I have found favor in your eyes, please excuse me so I can go and see my brothers.’ That is why he has not come to the king’s table.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul’s anger burned against Jonathan, and he said to him, “You son of a perverted, unfaithful woman! Don’t I know that you have chosen the son of Jesse to your own shame and to the shame of your mother’s nakedness?
speaker: Narrator

text: For as long as the son of Jesse lives on this earth, you will not be established, nor will your kingship. So send for him and bring him to me, because he must surely die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan answered his father Saul, “Why should he be put to death? What has he done?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul threw his spear at him to hit him. So Jonathan knew that his father was determined to put David to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan got up from the table in fierce anger, and he ate no food on the second day of the month, for he grieved for David, because his father had treated David so shamefully.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning Jonathan went out into the field at the time he had set with David. He took a young servant boy with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his boy, “Run out and find the arrows that I shoot.” As the boy ran, Jonathan shot an arrow beyond him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the boy reached the area where Jonathan’s arrow had landed, Jonathan yelled to the boy, “Isn’t the arrow farther out from you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan shouted to the boy, “Go faster! Hurry up! Don’t be slow!” Jonathan’s boy picked up the arrows and came back to his master.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boy did not know anything about what was going on. Only Jonathan and David knew.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan gave his equipment to his boy and told him, “Go on ahead. Carry these things into the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as the boy was gone, David got up from the south side of the mound. He fell down with his face to the ground and bowed three times. They kissed one another and wept together, but David wept more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan said to David, “Go in peace, because we have both sworn in the Lord’s name. May the Lord stand between you and me and between my offspring and your offspring forever.” David got up and left, and Jonathan went back into the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: David came to Ahimelek the priest at Nob. When he came to meet David, Ahimelek was trembling with fear, and he said to David, “Why are you alone? Why isn’t there anyone with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Ahimelek the priest, “The king sent me on a mission and told me, ‘Don’t let anyone know anything about where I am sending you or about your orders.’ I have instructed the young men to wait for me at a certain place.
speaker: Narrator

text: So what do you have on hand? Please give me five loaves of bread, or whatever is available.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest answered David, “I do not have any ordinary bread, but there is holy bread—I can give it to you only if your young men have kept themselves away from women.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David answered the priest, “Yes indeed, women have been kept away from us just as they have been on previous occasions. Whenever I go out on a mission, the bodies of the young men are kept holy even if it is only an ordinary journey. How much more then shall their bodies be holy today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest gave him holy bread, because there was no bread there except for the Bread of the Presence which had been removed from the presence of the Lord and replaced with hot bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now one of Saul’s servants was present that day, detained before the Lord. His name was Doeg the Edomite. He was in charge of Saul’s shepherds.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Ahimelek, “Don’t you have a spear or sword on hand here? I didn’t bring my sword or my gear with me, because the king’s mission was so urgent.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The priest said, “The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the Valley of Elah, is here. It is wrapped in a cloth behind the place where the special vest is kept. If you would like to take that, take it, because there is nothing else here.”
David said, “There is no other like that one. Give it to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David quickly fled from Saul that day and went to Achish king of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: The officials of Achish said to him, “Isn’t this David, the king of the land? Didn’t they dance and sing songs about him, saying, ‘Saul has slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David took those words to heart, so he was very afraid of Achish king of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: He changed his behavior in their presence and pretended to be insane while he was in their hands. He scribbled on the doors of the gate, and let his spit run down his beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Achish said to his servants, “Look, can’t you see that the man is insane? Why have you brought him to me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t I have enough madmen? Did you have to bring this madman into my presence? Should I keep this man in my house?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David departed from there and escaped to the cave at Adullam. When his brothers and his father’s entire household heard about it, they went down to join him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who was in distress, everyone who was in debt, and everyone who was discontented gathered around him, and he became their commander. There were about four hundred men with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went from there to Mizpah in Moab, and he said to the king of Moab, “Please let my father and mother come and stay with you, until I find out what God will do for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he brought them to the king of Moab, and they stayed with him the whole time that David was in the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet Gad said to David, “Do not stay in the stronghold. Leave and go to the land of Judah.” So David left and went to the Forest of Hereth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul heard that David and the men with him had been located.
Saul was sitting under the tamarisk tree on an elevated location in Gibeah. He had his spear in his hand, and all his attendants were standing around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to his attendants who were standing around him, “Listen, you Benjaminites! Will the son of Jesse give every one of you fields and vineyards? Will he make you all officers over thousands and officers over hundreds?
speaker: Narrator

text: So why have all of you conspired against me? Why is there no one who informs me when my son makes a covenant with the son of Jesse? Why is there not one of you who sympathizes with me or informs me that my son has stirred up my servant against me, so that he is waiting to ambush me, as he is today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Doeg the Edomite, who was standing beside Saul’s attendants, replied, “I saw the son of Jesse come to Ahimelek son of Ahitub at Nob.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest inquired of the Lord for him and gave him supplies and the sword of Goliath the Philistine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king summoned the priest, Ahimelek son of Ahitub, along with all of his father’s house, that is, all the priests who were in Nob, and all of them came to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul said, “Listen, you son of Ahitub.”
He answered, “I am listening, my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said to him, “Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse, by giving him bread and a sword and inquiring of God for him, so that he can rise up against me and lie in ambush, as he is doing today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ahimelek answered the king, “Who among all your servants is as faithful as David? He is the king’s son-in-law, the head of your elite troops, and is honored in your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have I just begun to inquire of God for him today? Certainly not! The king should not charge anything against his servant or against all the house of my father, for your servant knows nothing at all about this matter, in whole or in part.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “You shall certainly die, Ahimelek, you and all your father’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king said to the bodyguards who were standing around him, “Turn and kill the priests of the Lord, because their hand too is with David. They knew that he was fleeing, but they did not inform me.”
But the attendants of the king would not raise a hand against the priests of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said to Doeg, “You turn and attack the priests!”
Doeg the Edomite turned and attacked the priests. On that day he killed eighty-five men who wore the special linen garment.
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck Nob, the city of the priests, with the edge of the sword, both men and women, children and nursing babies, as well as cattle, donkeys, and sheep—all of them with the edge of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: But one of the sons of Ahimelek son of Ahitub, whose name was Abiathar, escaped and fled to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abiathar told David that Saul had killed the Lord’s priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Abiathar, “On that day when Doeg the Edomite was present, I knew without a doubt that he would tell Saul. I am responsible for the death of all the members of your father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay with me. Do not be afraid, for the one who seeks my life also seeks your life. You will be safe with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David was told, “Here’s news! The Philistines are fighting against Keilah and plundering the threshing floors.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So David inquired of the Lord, “Shall I go and strike these Philistines?”
The Lord said to David, “Go strike the Philistines and save Keilah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David’s men said to him, “Look how afraid we are here in Judah! How much more then if we go to Keilah against the armies of the Philistines!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David inquired of the Lord again, and the Lord answered him, “Set out and go down to Keilah, for I will deliver the Philistines into your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his men went to Keilah and fought against the Philistines. He took away their livestock and struck a heavy blow against the Philistines. David saved the inhabitants of Keilah.
speaker: Narrator

text: (When Abiathar son of Ahimelek fled with David to Keilah, he had brought the special vest, which was in his possession.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul was told that David had gone to Keilah, he said, “God has delivered him into my hand, since David has trapped himself by entering a city that has barred gates.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul summoned all the fighting men to go down to Keilah to besiege David and his men.
speaker: Narrator

text: David knew that Saul was planning to harm him, so he said to Abiathar the priest, “Bring the special vest here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said, “O Lord, the God of Israel, your servant has heard a specific report that Saul plans to come to Keilah to destroy the city because of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will the citzens of Keilah hand me over to him? Will Saul come down, as your servant has heard? O Lord, God of Israel, please tell your servant.”
The Lord said, “He will come down.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then David asked, “Will the citizens of Keilah hand me and my men over to Saul?”
The Lord said, “They will hand you over.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and his men, who numbered about six hundred, immediately departed from Keilah and went wherever they could. When Saul was told that David had escaped from Keilah, he gave up his plan to go there.
speaker: Narrator

text: David stayed in the strongholds in the wilderness. He remained in the hill country of the Wilderness of Ziph. Saul searched for him every day, but God did not deliver him into his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David knew that Saul had come to seek his life.
David was at Horesh in the Wilderness of Ziph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul’s son Jonathan set out and came to David at Horesh. There he strengthened his hand in God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Do not be afraid, because the hand of my father Saul will not find you. You will be king over Israel, and I will be second to you. Even my father Saul knows that.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They both made a covenant before the Lord. Then David stayed at Horesh, and Jonathan returned home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Ziphites came to Saul at Gibeah and said, “Do you know that David is hiding near us in the strongholds at Horesh near the Hill of Hakilah, in the southern part of the badlands?
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, O King, come down! Come down whenever you wish to come, and our role will be to deliver him up into the king’s hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul said, “May you be blessed by the Lord, for you have sympathized with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and make sure that you know exactly where he is and who has seen him there, for I have been told that he is very wily.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make sure that you know all the places where he hides. Then come back to me with solid information. Then I will come with you. If he is in the land, you can be sure that I will hunt him down among all the thousands of Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Saul’s men set out and went to Ziph ahead of Saul.
Meanwhile David and his men were in the Wilderness of Maon, in the Arabah, south of the badlands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul and his men went to look for David. When David was told about it, he went down to the rock and stayed in the Wilderness of Maon. When Saul heard that, he pursued David in the Wilderness of Maon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was going along one side of the mountain, and David and his men were on the other side. David hurried to get away from Saul and his men, who were trying to surround David and his men in order to capture them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a messenger came to Saul and said, “Hurry! Come back, because the Philistines have made a raid on the land!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul turned back from pursuing David and went to confront the Philistines. That is why that place is named Sela Hamahlekoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David went up from there and stayed in the strongholds of En Gedi.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul had returned from pursuing the Philistines, he was told, “Here’s some news. David is in the Wilderness of En Gedi.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul took three thousand specially chosen men from all Israel and went to hunt for David and his men along the rocky slopes of the wild goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul came to some sheep pens that were along that route. Saul went into a cave that was there to relieve himself. At that time David and his men were far back in the interior of the cave.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s men said to him, “Look, this is the day the Lord told you about when he said, ‘I will deliver your enemy into your hand, and you will do to him whatever seems good to you.’” So David got up and cut off the edge of Saul’s robe without being noticed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward, David had a guilty conscience, because he had cut off the edge of Saul’s robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his men, “May I be cursed if I do something like this to my master, who is the Lord’s anointed—that I would stretch out my hand against him, since he is the Lord’s anointed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
With these words David restrained his men and did not allow them to attack Saul.
Saul got up, left the cave, and went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David got up and followed him out of the cave and shouted to him, “My lord the king!”
When Saul looked back at him, David bowed facedown to the ground to show respect.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Saul, “Why do you listen to the words of people who say, ‘Watch out! David is seeking to harm you’?
speaker: Narrator

text: This very day you have seen with your own eyes how the Lord delivered you into my hand in the cave. Some urged me to kill you, but I spared you, because I said, ‘I will not stretch out my hand against my master, because he is the Lord’s anointed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Take a look at this! My father, take a good look at the piece of your robe that is here in my hand. Because I cut off the edge of your robe but did not kill you, you can be sure that I do not have any evil intent and I am not rebelling. I have not sinned against you, even though you keep hunting for me to take my life.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord judge between you and me, and may the Lord avenge me on you, but my hand will not be against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the ancient proverb says, ‘Out of the wicked come wicked deeds,’ but my hand will not be against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Against whom has the king of Israel come out? What are you pursuing? A dead dog? A flea?
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord, therefore, be the judge who renders a verdict between you and me. May he examine my case, plead my cause, and deliver me out of your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had finished speaking these words, Saul responded, “Is that your voice, David, my son?” Saul broke down and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to David, “You are more righteous than I, for you have treated me well, but I have treated you badly.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have made it clear today how you have been good to me, because when the Lord delivered me into your hand, you did not kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man finds his enemy, will he let him go away unharmed? May the Lord reward you with good for what you have done for me today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I know without a doubt that you will become king, and that the kingship over Israel will be established in your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: So swear to me now by the Lord that you will not cut off my descendants after me and that you will not destroy my name from my father’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David promised this to Saul with an oath.
Saul went back home, but David and his men went up to the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel died. All Israel gathered together and mourned for him. They buried him at his house in Ramah.
Then David set out and went down to the Wilderness of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man in Maon who made his livelihood in Carmel. This man was very wealthy. He had three thousand sheep and a thousand goats, and he was shearing his sheep at Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man’s name was Nabal, and his wife’s name was Abigail. This woman had good judgment and was beautiful, but her husband was a harsh, unbending man, who behaved badly. He was from the family line of Caleb.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the wilderness David heard that Nabal was shearing his sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David sent ten young men and told them, “Go up to Carmel. Approach Nabal and wish him peace in my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell him this: ‘Long life to you! Peace be with you! Peace be with your household! Peace be with all that you have!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I hear that you are shearing sheep. Your shepherds have recently been with us, and we did not harm them. Nothing was missing from them the whole time they were in Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ask your young men, and they will tell you. Therefore let my young men find favor with you, for we have come on a good day. Please give whatever you can to your servants and to your son David.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David’s men came and said all those things to Nabal in the name of David. When they had finished,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nabal answered David’s servants, “Who is David? Who is the son of Jesse? There are so many servants breaking away from their masters these days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Should I take my bread, my water, and my meat that I have butchered for my shearers and give it to men when I do not know where they come from?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David’s men left and went on their way. They came back and told David all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David said to his men, “Each of you, strap on your sword!”
So every man strapped on his sword. David also strapped on his sword. About four hundred men followed David, and two hundred stayed with the supplies.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of Nabal’s young men told Abigail, Nabal’s wife, “Listen to me. You need to know what happened. David sent messengers from the wilderness to greet our master, but he screamed insults at them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those men have been very good to us, and we have not been harmed, nor have we had anything missing the entire time we were in the countryside with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were a wall around us night and day, the whole time we were among them while we were taking care of the sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: So carefully consider what you should do, for they are determined to bring disaster on our master and on his entire household, since he is such a worthless good-for-nothing that no one can talk to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abigail hurried and took two hundred loaves of bread, two containers of wine, five sheep that were already prepared, a bushel of roasted grain, one hundred clumps of raisins, and two hundred cakes of dried figs. She loaded these supplies on donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to her young men, “Go on ahead of me. I will follow right after you.” But she did not tell her husband, Nabal.
speaker: Narrator

text: As she rode on her donkey and came down to the secluded trail on the mountain, she saw that David and his men were coming down toward her, and she met them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David had said, “It was all for nothing that I have protected everything that this fellow has in the wilderness, so that nothing was missing from everything that belonged to him. But he has repaid me evil for good.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God punish the enemies of David severely and double it, if by the morning light I leave alive so much as one person who urinates against a wall.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abigail saw David, she hurried and got off her donkey. She bowed and fell facedown on the ground in David’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: She fell at his feet and said, “To me, my lord—charge the guilt to me! Please let your servant speak to you. Listen to the words of your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please, my lord, do not pay attention to this worthless good-for-nothing Nabal, for he is exactly what his name suggests. Nabal is his name, and foolishness is never far from him. But I, your servant, did not see my lord’s young men, whom you sent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, my lord, as the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, since the Lord has held you back from the guilt of bloodshed and from avenging yourself with your own hand, now let your enemies and those who seek to do evil against my lord be like Nabal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please distribute this gift that I, your servant, have brought to my lord for the young men who follow my lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please forgive your servant’s offense. For the Lord will certainly make an enduring house for my lord, because my lord is fighting the Lord’s battles. May no evil be found in you all your days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though men may rise up to pursue you and to seek your life, may the life of my lord be safely wrapped up in the bundle of the living, with the Lord your God. But the lives of your enemies he will hurl away like a stone from the pocket of a sling.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, when the Lord has done for my lord all the good things that he has spoken concerning you, and he has appointed you leader over Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: you will not be burdened by grief or a guilty conscience because you, my lord, have shed blood without cause or have avenged yourself. Then, when the Lord has dealt well with you, my lord, remember your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Abigail, “Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, who sent you to meet me today!
speaker: Narrator

text: Your good judgment is blessed, and you are blessed, because today you have kept me from the guilt of shedding blood and from avenging myself with my own hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: For truly, as the Lord, the God of Israel, lives, who has kept me from harming you, unless you had come quickly to meet me, certainly by the morning light there would not have been left for Nabal so much as one person who urinates against a wall.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David received from her hand what she had brought for him. Then he said to her, “Go up to your house in peace. You see, I have listened to your voice and have shown you favor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abigail came to Nabal and saw that he was holding a feast in his house, a feast fit for a king. Nabal was in good spirits, because he had drunk a lot. So she told him nothing at all until the morning light.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning, when the wine had worn off for Nabal, his wife told him about these things, and his heart died within him, and he became like a stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: About ten days later, the Lord struck Nabal, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When David heard that Nabal was dead, he said, “Blessed be the Lord, who has passed judgment on Nabal’s insults against me and has kept his servant from doing evil. The Lord has returned the evil done by Nabal back on his own head.”
Then David sent messengers to make arrangements with Abigail for him to take her as his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David’s servants came to Abigail at Carmel, they spoke to her and said, “David has sent us to you to bring you to him as his wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She got up and bowed down with her face to the ground. She said, “Behold. I, your humblest servant, am here ready to wash the feet of the servants of my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abigail hurried and set out, riding on a donkey, with five young women who were her attendants following her. She went with the messengers of David and became his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also married Ahinoam of Jezre’el, so they both became his wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Saul gave his daughter Michal, who was David’s wife, to Palti son of Laish, who was from Gallim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ziphites came to Saul at Gibeah and said, “Do you know that David is hiding at the Hill of Hakilah, which is near the badlands?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul set out and went down to the Wilderness of Ziph with three thousand men, who were specially chosen from Israel, to search for David in the Wilderness of Ziph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul set up camp near the road at the Hill of Hakilah, which is near the badlands. David, however, stayed in the wilderness. When David heard that Saul had come into the wilderness to search for him,
speaker: Narrator

text: he sent out scouts, who confirmed that Saul had come.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David moved out and came to the place where Saul had set up camp. David saw where Saul was sleeping near Abner son of Ner, the commander of his army. Saul was sleeping inside the defensive perimeter of the camp, and the rest of the men were camped around him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David responded to the situation by saying to Ahimelek the Hittite and to Joab’s brother, Abishai son of Zeruiah, “Who will go down with me into the camp, to Saul?”
Abishai said, “I will go down with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So during the night David and Abishai passed through the people in the camp, and they saw that Saul was sleeping inside the defensive perimeter of the camp, with his spear stuck into the ground beside his head. Abner and the rest of the men were lying all around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abishai said to David, “God has delivered your enemy into your hand today. Please let me strike him and pin him to the ground with my spear. One blow! That’s all I’ll need! I won’t need to strike him a second time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But David said to Abishai, “Do not destroy him, for who can stretch out his hand against the Lord’s anointed and be guiltless?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David continued, “As the Lord lives, the Lord will strike him, or his day will come and he will die, or he will go down into battle and be swept away.
speaker: Narrator

text: May I be cursed if I stretch out my hand against the Lord’s anointed. Now go and take the spear that is beside his head and the jar of water, and we will go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David took the spear and the jar of water that were next to Saul’s head, and they left. No one saw them. No one knew anything. No one woke up. They were all sound asleep, because a deep sleep from the Lord had fallen on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David moved over to a position across from the camp and stood on the top of the mountain some distance away. There was a lot of space between them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David then shouted to the people and to Abner son of Ner, “Abner, are you going to answer?”
Abner responded, “Who are you to be shouting at the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Abner, “Aren’t you a man? Who is like you in Israel? So why haven’t you kept watch over your lord, the king? For someone came into the camp to destroy your lord the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: This thing that you have done is not good. As the Lord lives, you deserve to die, because all of you have not kept watch over your master, the Lord’s anointed. Now look around! Where are the king’s spear and the jar of water that was next to his head?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul recognized David’s voice and said, “Is this your voice, David, my son?”
David said, “It is my voice, my lord the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He added, “Why does my lord pursue his servant? What have I done? What evil is there in my hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: So please, let my lord the king listen to the words of his servant. If it is the Lord who has stirred you up against me, let him accept an offering. But if it is other people, may they be cursed before the Lord, for they have driven me out today so that I cannot remain in my share of the Lord’s inheritance. They keep saying, ‘Go, serve other gods!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, do not let my blood fall to the earth away from the presence of the Lord, for the king of Israel has come out searching for a flea, or like someone who hunts for a partridge in the mountains.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Saul said, “I have sinned. Come back, David my son, for I will not harm you anymore, because my life was precious in your eyes today. I have acted like a fool and have made a terrible mistake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David responded, “Look, here is your spear, O King! Let one of the young men come over and get it.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord deal with every man according to his righteousness and his faithfulness, because the Lord handed you over to me today, but I would not stretch out my hand against the Lord’s anointed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as your life was precious in my eyes today, so let my life be precious in the Lord’s eyes, and let him deliver me from all persecution.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Saul said to David, “May you be blessed, David my son. You will certainly accomplish great things, and you will certainly remain successful.”
So David went on his way, and Saul returned to his own place.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to himself, “Any day now I will be swept away by the hand of Saul. The best plan for me is to escape immediately to the land of the Philistines. Then Saul will give up searching for me within the borders of Israel, and I will escape out of his hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David set out with the six hundred men who were with him and crossed over to Achish son of Maok, king of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: David stayed with Achish at Gath—he and his men, each man with his family, including David with his two wives, Ahinoam from Jezre’el and Abigail from Carmel, who had been Nabal’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul was told that David had fled to Gath, so he did not continue searching for him anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Achish, “If I have now found favor in your eyes, assign me a place to live in one of the towns in the countryside. Why should your servant live in the royal city with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that day Achish gave him Ziklag. That is why Ziklag belongs to the kings of Judah to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The length of time that David spent in the territory of the Philistines was a year and four months.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and his men would go out and raid the Geshurites, the Girzites, and the Amalekites—peoples who had been living in the land for a very long time. Their territory extended from the beginning of Shur all the way to the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever David attacked a land, he did not leave even one man or woman alive. He would carry off the sheep, the cattle, the donkeys, the camels, and the clothing. Then he would return and come back to Achish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Achish would ask, “Where have you carried out a raid today?”
David would answer, “Against the Negev of Judah,” or “Against the Negev of the Jerahme’elites,” or “Against the Negev of the Kenites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David would not keep even one man or woman alive to bring them to Gath. He said, “If I do, they would inform on us. They would say, ‘This is what David did, and this is what he has been doing the entire time he has been living in the territory of the Philistines.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Achish trusted David, and he said, “He has made himself a real stench to his people Israel, so he will remain my servant forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days, the Philistines brought together their armies to prepare for war against Israel. Achish said to David, “You certainly understand that you must go along with me in the army, you and your men.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David said to Achish, “When I do, you will know what your servant can do.”
Achish said to David, “When you do, I will make you my bodyguard permanently.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
At this time, Samuel was dead, and all Israel had mourned for him and buried him in Ramah, which was his hometown.
Saul had banished the mediums and spiritists from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines joined forces and set up camp at Shunem. Saul brought all Israel together, and they set up camp at Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Saul saw the army of the Philistines, he was terrified and trembled with fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul inquired of the Lord, but the Lord did not answer him through dreams, or through Urim, or through prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Saul said to his attendants, “Find a woman who consults the spirits of the dead for me, so that I can go to her and inquire of her.”
His servants said to him, “As a matter of fact, there is a woman at Endor who consults the spirits of the dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul disguised himself and put on different clothing. Then he went with two men, and they visited the woman at night. He said, “Please consult a spirit for me. Bring up for me the person I name to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman said to him, “Look, you must know what Saul has done. He has cut off mediums and spiritists from the land. Why then are you setting a death trap for me, to make me die?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul swore to her by the Lord, “As the Lord lives, you will not be punished for this.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the woman said, “Who is it that you want me to bring up for you?”
He said, “Bring up Samuel for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the woman saw Samuel, she screamed and said to Saul, “Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said to her, “Do not be afraid! What do you see?”
The woman said to Saul, “I see a powerful spirit coming up out of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to her, “What does he look like?”
She said, “An old man is coming up. He is covered with a robe.” Saul recognized that it was Samuel, and he bowed with his face to the ground to show respect.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samuel said to Saul, “Why have you disturbed me by bringing me up?”
Saul answered, “I am in dire straits because the Philistines are waging war against me, and God has departed from me. He no longer answers me through prophets or through dreams. That is why I have called you, so that you can let me know what I should do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samuel said, “Why do you ask me, since the Lord has departed from you and has become your adversary?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has done exactly what he told you through me. The Lord has torn the kingdom out of your hand and given it to your neighbor David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you did not obey the Lord’s voice and did not execute his fierce wrath on Amalek, the Lord has done this to you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: What’s more, the Lord will deliver Israel into the hands of the Philistines, along with you. Tomorrow you and your sons will be with me. The Lord will also deliver the army of Israel into the hand of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul immediately fell full-length on the ground. Not only was he terrified because of Samuel’s words, but he also had no strength left because he had eaten no food all that day and all that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman came to Saul and saw that he was terrified. So she said to him, “Look, your servant has obeyed you, and I have taken my life in my hands. I have listened to the words you spoke to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now please listen to your servant, and allow me to set some food in front of you. Eat, so that you will have strength when you go on your way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Saul refused and said, “I will not eat.” But his attendants, together with the woman, strongly urged him, and he listened to them. So he got up off the ground and sat on the bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman had a fattened calf at the house. She quickly butchered it. She took flour, kneaded it, and baked unleavened bread with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: She set it before Saul and his servants, and they ate. Then they got up and left during the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines gathered all their armies together at Aphek, and the Israelites camped beside the spring at Jezre’el.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the serens of the Philistines were marching past with their units of a hundred and units of a thousand, David and his men were marching in the rear of the column with Achish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The officers of the Philistines said, “What are these Hebrews doing here?”
Achish said to the officers of the Philistines, “Isn’t this David, the servant of Saul, king of Israel, who has been with me for some time now? I have found no fault in him from the day he defected, right up to today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the officers of the Philistines were angry with him, and the officers of the Philistines said, “Make this man return to the place that you have assigned to him. He must not go down to battle with us, or else he might become an adversary against us during the battle. What better way for this man to reconcile himself to his master than with the heads of these men of ours?
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t this David, about whom they sang to one another as they danced, ‘Saul has slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Achish called David and said to him, “As the Lord lives, you have been straightforward with me. As far as I am concerned, it would be good to have you accompany me on this campaign, because I have not found anything wrong with you from the day you came to me right up to this day. Nevertheless, in the opinion of the serens you are a liability.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now return. Go in peace, so that you do not displease the serens of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Achish, “But what have I done? What have you found in your servant from the day I came into your presence until this day that would disqualify me from going and fighting against the enemies of my lord the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Achish answered David, “I know that, as far as I am concerned, you are as good as an angel of God. Nevertheless, the officers of the Philistines have said, ‘He must not go up to the battle with us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So get up early in the morning, along with the servants of your master who have come with you. Get up early in the morning, and leave as soon as it is light.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David got up early, and he and his men left early in the morning to return to the land of the Philistines, but the Philistines went up to Jezre’el.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David and his men arrived at Ziklag on the third day.
In the meantime the Amalekites had raided the Negev and Ziklag. They had attacked Ziklag and burned it down.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had taken the women captive, along with everyone who was there, from the least to the greatest. They did not kill anyone, but they carried them off and went on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when David and his men came to the city, they saw that it had been burned and that their wives, their sons, and their daughters had been taken captive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and the troops who were with him wept loudly, until they had no more strength to weep.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s two wives had been taken captive, namely, Ahinoam from Jezre’el and Abigail, who had been the wife of Nabal from Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was under a great deal of pressure because his men were talking about stoning him. The spirit of every one of them was very bitter because of their sons and daughters, but David found strength in the Lord his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Abiathar the priest, the son of Ahimelek, “Bring the special vest of the priest here to me.” So Abiathar brought the special vest to David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David inquired of the Lord, “Should I pursue this band of raiders? Will I overtake them?”
The Lord answered him, “Pursue! You will certainly overtake them and recover everything.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David set out with the six hundred men who were with him. When they came to the stream called the Besor, the men who were unable to keep up stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: David pursued with four hundred men, because two hundred stayed behind, so exhausted that they could not get across the ravine of the Besor.
speaker: Narrator

text: They found an Egyptian in the open country and brought him to David. They gave him bread to eat and water to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also gave him a piece from a cake of figs and two clusters of raisins. When he had eaten, he was revived. (He had eaten no bread and had drunk no water for three days and three nights.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
David asked him, “Whose servant are you? Where are you from?”
The young man said, “I am from Egypt, a slave to an Amalekite. My master left me behind when I became sick three days ago.
speaker: Narrator

text: We made a raid on the Negev of the Kerethites, and on the territory of Judah, and on the Negev of Caleb, and we burned Ziklag.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David said to him, “Will you bring me down to this raiding party?”
He said, “Swear to me by God that you will not kill me or hand me over to my master, and I will bring you down to this raiding party.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had brought David to them, there the Amalekites were, scattered all over the place! They were eating, drinking, and celebrating because of the great amount of plunder that they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from the land of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: David attacked them from twilight until the evening of the next day. Not a man of them escaped from there, except four hundred young men who rode off on camels and escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: David recovered everything that the Amalekites had taken. David also rescued his two wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was nothing missing, from the least to the greatest, neither sons nor daughters, nor any plunder, nor anything else that they had taken with them. David brought it all back.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took all the flocks and the herds, which they drove ahead of the other livestock, and the men were saying, “This is David’s plunder.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David approached the two hundred men whom they had left at the Besor because they were too exhausted to follow him, they went out to meet David and the men who were with him. David came up to the men who had been left behind and wished them well,
speaker: Narrator

text: but all the wicked men and worthless troublemakers among those who had accompanied David responded, “Because they did not go with us, we will not give them anything from the plunder that we have recovered, except we will give every man his wife and his children, so that he can take them and leave.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said, “Do not act that way, my brothers, with what the Lord has given to us. He is the one who has preserved us and delivered into our hand the raiders who came against us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who can listen to this proposal of yours? No, the same share that is given to the one who goes down to the battle will be given to the one who stays with the supplies. They shall have an equal share.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So from that day forward, David made this a rule and precedent for Israel that lasts to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David came to Ziklag, he sent some of the plunder to the elders of Judah, who were sympathetic to him, and said, “Look, here is a blessing for you from the plunder taken from the Lord’s enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent it to the elders who were in Bethel, Ramoth Negev, Jattir,
speaker: Narrator

text: Aroer, Siphmoth, Eshtemoa,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Rakal; to those who were in the towns of the Jerahme’elites and the towns of the Kenites;
speaker: Narrator

text: to those who were in Hormah, Borashan, and Athak;
speaker: Narrator

text: to those who were in Hebron and all the other places where David himself and his men had wandered.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the meantime, the Philistines were fighting against Israel, and the men of Israel fled from the Philistines and fell mortally wounded at Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines were closing in on Saul and his sons. They struck down Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malkishua, the sons of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The attack directed at Saul was fierce. The archers targeted him and hit him, and he was seriously wounded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Saul said to his armor bearer, “Draw your sword and run me through with it, so that these uncircumcised fellows cannot come and run me through and abuse me!”
But his armor bearer would not do it, because he was too afraid. So Saul took his own sword and fell on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his armor bearer saw that Saul was dead, he too fell on his sword and died with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul died together with his three sons, his armor bearer, and all his men, all on that same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Israel from the other side of the valley and those from beyond the Jordan saw that the men of Israel had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities and fled. Then the Philistines came and lived in those cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day, when the Philistines came to strip those who had been killed in the battle, they found Saul and his three sons fallen at Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cut off his head, stripped off his armor, and sent messengers throughout the land of the Philistines to carry the good news to the temple of their idols and to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put his armor and weapons in the temple of the Ashtartes, and they fastened his body to the wall of Beth Shan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the inhabitants of Jabesh Gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
speaker: Narrator

text: all the strong, courageous men set out, traveled all night, and took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons down from the wall of Beth Shan. They returned to Jabesh and burned them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took their bones and buried them under the tamarisk tree in Jabesh and fasted seven days.
speaker: Narrator
